messages.content: What is the first know human city ?

The first known human cities emerged in ancient Mesopotamia, in modern-day Iraq. Some of the earliest cities include:

• Uruk - Emerged around 3200 BCE, considered by many archaeologists to be the first true city. It had a population of between 20,000 to 50,000 people at its peak. The city was home to many important developments such as the invention of writing.

• Ur - A major city that emerged around 3800 BCE. It was an important Sumerian city and considered a center of civilization. Ur reached its peak around 2100 BCE under the rule of the 3rd dynasty of Ur.

• Jericho - Located in the West Bank, Jericho is one of the earliest known cities, with settlements dating back to around 9000 BCE. The city was fortified around 6800 BCE, with a population of 2,000-3,000 people.

• Catalhoyuk - A large Neolithic settlement in southern Anatolia, in modern-day Turkey. Inhabited between 7500 BCE to 5700 BCE, with a population between 3,000 to 8,000 people at its peak. It was a very early example of urbanization, with closely packed mudbrick houses.

• Eridu - Considered by some to be the first city in Mesopotamia, with habitation going back to around 5400 BCE. The city was considered the home of Enki, the god of water in the Sumerian pantheon. It was a major Sumerian city and center of trade and religion.

So in summary, the first known human cities emerged in Mesopotamia, especially in modern-day Iraq, around 3500 BCE. These were some of the earliest cradles of civilization, with advancements such as writing, trade, and agriculture.
and that city found in turkey with more than 8 thousands years ?

You're probably referring to Çatalhöyük, a very early Neolithic settlement located in southern Anatolia, Turkey. It dates back to around 7,500 BCE to 5,700 BCE, making it one of the earliest large human settlements ever found. At its peak, Çatalhöyük had a population of 3,000 to 8,000 people.

Some key facts about Çatalhöyük:

• It was a very early example of urbanization. The settlement consisted of closely packed mudbrick houses, with little space between them.

• The settlement was located in a very fertile area, allowing its inhabitants to rely on agriculture and farming. They grew crops such as wheat, barley and lentils, and raised livestock such as sheep and goats.

• The site provides early evidence of pottery, weaving, woodworking, and possibly even the earliest form of bread. Domesticated animals were also present.

• The settlement lacked streets and public squares. People entered houses through the roof, using ladders. The rooftops were also used for waste disposal and storage.

• There is evidence of art and spirituality. The walls of some houses feature frescoes and relief sculptures. Statues and figurines representing the female form have also been found, indicating the people may have worshipped a mother goddess.

• The reasons for the eventual abandonment of Çatalhöyük are still a mystery. It may have been due to overpopulation, disease, conflict or climate change. Its inhabitants likely dispersed into smaller villages.

• Çatalhöyük provides valuable insights into the transition from hunter-gatherer groups to agricultural settlements in the Neolithic era. It is recognized as a UNESCO World Heritage Site.

So in summary, Çatalhöyük was one of the earliest and most sophisticated Neolithic settlements ever found. Its age, size, and features provide a glimpse into how some of the earliest farming communities lived and functioned.
Why this place is not a city ?

Çatalhöyük is considered by some archaeologists to be a very early precursor to cities, but it lacks some key features of a true city:

1. No public infrastructure: Çatalhöyük lacked public buildings, plazas, streets and open spaces. All activities seemed to take place within the confines of private buildings. True cities have public infrastructure like streets, public buildings and marketplaces.

2. No clear social hierarchy: There is little evidence of a clear ruling class or social elite at Çatalhöyük. Although some houses were larger, indicating higher status, the overall settlement seemed quite egalitarian. True cities usually have a clear social hierarchy and elite ruling class.

3. Lack of specialized professions: There is little evidence of specialized craftsmen or artisans at Çatalhöyük. Most inhabitants seemed to practice subsistence farming or agriculture. True cities contain specialized professions like metalworkers, priests, and administrative classes.

4. No political institutions: There is no evidence of a centralized government, administrative center or political institutions at Çatalhöyük. Decision making seemed to take place at a local level. True cities are usually organized under some kind of political authority or institution.

5. Lack of cultural complexity: Although Çatalhöyük does show signs of art, ritual and spirituality, its culture remained quite homogeneous. True cities usually contain a diversity of cultural and ethnic groups, with cultural traditions that have been accumulated over time.

So in summary, while Çatalhöyük was a large, long-lasting and in some ways sophisticated settlement, it lacked many of the key features that define a true urban city. It had no public infrastructure, clear social hierarchy, specialized professions, political institutions or cultural complexity. It was more akin to a large farming village than a city. Still, it provides valuable insights into how prehistoric societies first began to urbanize.
